name: Axiom Coherence Inner Product Formalization
description: The mathematical formalization of the Coherence Inner Product Axiom, defining the inner product on the prime coordinate space and its properties as a Euclidean inner product.
text:
The Coherence Inner Product Axiom can be formalized with precise mathematical notation to capture its essential definition and properties.

On the prime coordinate space ℤ^(P), which consists of integer vectors indexed by the set of primes P, we define the inner product as a function ⟨·,·⟩: ℤ^(P) × ℤ^(P) → ℝ that maps each pair of coordinate vectors to a real number:

⟨v,w⟩ = ∑_p v(p)·w(p)

where v(p) and w(p) denote the components of vectors v and w corresponding to prime p. This is the standard dot product applied to the prime coordinate vectors.

For objects X and Y with prime factorizations yielding prime coordinates φ(X) and φ(Y), their inner product is expressed as:

⟨φ(X),φ(Y)⟩ = ∑_p φ(X)(p)·φ(Y)(p)

This inner product satisfies all the axioms required of a Euclidean inner product:

1. Symmetry: ⟨v,w⟩ = ⟨w,v⟩ for all v, w ∈ ℤ^(P)

2. Linearity in the first argument: ⟨αv + βu, w⟩ = α⟨v,w⟩ + β⟨u,w⟩ for all scalars α, β and vectors u, v, w ∈ ℤ^(P)

3. Positive-definiteness: ⟨v,v⟩ ≥ 0 for all v ∈ ℤ^(P), with ⟨v,v⟩ = 0 if and only if v = 0

Furthermore, the prime basis elements form an orthonormal system, meaning:

⟨eᵢ,eⱼ⟩ = δᵢⱼ

where eᵢ and eⱼ are basis vectors corresponding to primes pᵢ and pⱼ, and δᵢⱼ is the Kronecker delta (equal to 1 if i = j and 0 otherwise). This formalizes the orthogonality of primes as structural dimensions.

The inner product induces the coherence norm through the relationship:

‖v‖ = √⟨v,v⟩

It also enables the definition of other geometric concepts:

- The angle θ between objects X and Y can be computed as:
  cos(θ) = ⟨φ(X),φ(Y)⟩ / (‖φ(X)‖·‖φ(Y)‖)

- The projection of object X onto object Y is given by:
  proj_Y(X) = ⟨φ(X),φ(Y)⟩/‖φ(Y)‖² · φ(Y)

These formal definitions create a complete Euclidean geometry on the prime coordinate space, enabling rich geometric analysis of structural relationships between objects.
